replies.msg:
From Bloomberg
Further comments on Huawei here, specifically in answer to a question about whether they will be removed from Commerce's blacklist:

"We're going to be supplying equipment from our companies."

"We are not discussing Huawei with President Xi yet. I want to see, before we start getting into that, I want to see where we end up."

"We have a national security problem, which to me is paramount. Very important."

Then again asked about removal from the list:

"We're talking about that. We have a meeting on that tomorrow or Tuesday."

quote.msg:
唔可以進入美國市場，
但可以繼續買零件用。

replies.msg:
初步睇係一人讓一步
美國俾華為買貨，但買咩貨我唔講住
而中共作為讓步會買農產品，但買咩農產品我又唔講住
以國際局勢黎講係起碼叫有做到野
但侵侵撚狗方法好多
我個人認為唔好跟車咁貼住

BTW
另一方面尋日安倍一黎就講香港
明示左一樣野，而家擺明東亞包圍網
日本作為美帝最大又最忠心既狗
同習帝講 i am watching you
香港一直以黎，係一直以黎都係中共俾西方「文明」世界既樣辦
而家有人出聲話你踩撚左界
就睇習帝到底為左刮錢敢唔敢郁
而侵侵前幾日有意無意暗示放權比日本解放自衛隊
或許係想加強日本作為美帝既東亞代言人力量


以個人黎講（撇除香港人身份先）
而家局勢係好值得觀望落去
互相消耗互相試探
到底邊一邊會跪係好值得睇落去

到作為香港人既一邊好無奈
我地永遠係一粒看似舉重輕重而又微不足道既棋子
可以轟動全世界言論
但又未必會有一個國家肯為我地直正出手做任何野
最無奈既係我地無能力親自做一啲野


最後一句：中共快啲仆街冚家剷

撚狗撚到
不過係香港嘅藍絲咪又係唔知，新聞唔報吖嘛

Trump told reporters he wouldn’t put additional tariffs on China for the “time being,” and that he’ll allow U.S. companies to supply Huawei Technologies Co.
Trump said he had not yet decided how to allow U.S. companies to continue selling to Huawei or whether to remove the tech giant from the Commerce Department’s entity list. He said he would meet with advisors next week to determine how to proceed.
“U.S. companies can sell their equipment to Huawei,” Trump said. “We’re talking about equipment where there’s no great national security problem with it.”
“I like our companies selling things to other people, so I allowed that to happen,’’ he said.
It was not clear how long the exemption would last. Trump said he had agreed with Xi to wait until the very end of trade talks to resolve broader issues around Huawei, including Washington’s lobbying campaign against allies buying its 5G equipment.
“Huawei is a complicated situation,” Trump said. “We’re leaving Huawei toward the end. We’ll see where we go with a trade agreement.”
